author: sky.cactus
content: Can I get some editor feedback on https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2494 ?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!425279588009246720> it sounds like you are able to confirm that `xlab` is one of the authors for https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2765 so I'll leave it to you to merge that (and I recommend helping the user update the email address to GH username as well).

author: sky.cactus
content: We *really* need to get the EIP bot to not listen in on forks.  Does anyone have any idea how to fix that?  The bot just recently pinged like 30 people: <https://github.com/vorot93/EIPs/pull/104> because someone merged master into their fork (essentially).

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm re-opening basically all of the auto-close-warning issues <@!425279588009246720>.

author: sky.cactus
content: I realize now that this bot's job was to trick me into addressing all of these Draft EIPs by putting them in my inbox.  üò¢

author: sky.cactus
content: So much for getting real work done today...

author: axic3354
content: Why are you reopening them?

author: axic3354
content: My takeaway is that we should have enable the bot once eipv has stronger checks in place, like checking for missing sections üôÇ

author: axic3354
content: Because that is one the notorious issues with all the pending drafts.

author: axic3354
content: <@!301186049323958275> I do not think you should review all the stale marked ones before the author pings that they are still interested. Otherwise this defeats the purpose.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Why are you reopening them?
<@!425279588009246720> I'm "touching" them because no editor actually asked for any changes originally, and so the bot's suggestion to close them or "fix the suggested edits" isn't reasonable.

author: axic3354
content: The majority of them fail on CI, so they were not even valid before editor comments.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> I do not think you should review all the stale marked ones before the author pings that they are still interested. Otherwise this defeats the purpose.
<@!425279588009246720> Hmm, you think we should just leave them with no editor feedback and just the bot telling them to respond to the editor feedback?

author: axic3354
content: I feel like there should be a bot complaining that "hey look, this fails ci, no editor will respond until that is fixed"

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, true.  I guess I could limit my commentary to EIPs that at least pass CI.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think you get an email from Travis if you fail CI?

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, probably only if you have a Travis account...

author: axic3354
content: Though one peculiar problem is that CI fails in every case because of the filename and missing number field, but I usually ignore that CI error and still comment, unless there are other major CI errors.

author: axic3354
content: So there's no good solution apart from making eipv check for sections, etc. and making a bot which displays the findings of eipv as comments on the PR.

author: axic3354
content: Should we disable the bot for the time being?

author: axic3354
content: Also I think using the github suggestions is a two edged sword: it makes it easy for submitters to click merge and hence making merging easy. In many cases they would not go to actually do the change themselves if they were only comments, which begs the question whether they will follow up after it is merged as a draft ü§î

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Should we disable the bot for the time being?
<@!425279588009246720> No, I don't think so.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Also I think using the github suggestions is a two edged sword: it makes it easy for submitters to click merge and hence making merging easy. In many cases they would not go to actually do the change themselves if they were only comments, which begs the question whether they will follow up after it is merged as a draft ü§î
<@!425279588009246720> If the user has been ignoring feedback I probably won't merge.  My suggestions and intention to merge after suggestions applied are for the ones where the user did everything right and the only reason their EIP isn't Draft is because *we* (editors) didn't do the right thing and give them prompt feedback.

author: sky.cactus
content: As someone who has had an EIP sit waiting on editors for over a year, I can appreciate their frustration at following all of the rules and still getting no progress.

author: axic3354
content: It is frustrating from all parties. People seriously struggle with git, and in many cases it takes them weeks to follow up (even when responding promptly at the time of submission, in my experience), and a handful of back and forth comments to get the validation to pass. My frustration is that almost nobody looks at the red CI mark, likely because they are unfamiliar with git -- hence we should have a bot post the issues from eipv.

author: axic3354
content: And because of this delay of them responding, it is often forgotten when they respond given the hundreds of other notifications. It is just really hard to manage this at 200 open PRs.

author: axic3354
content: Well, I definitely struggle üôÇ

author: axic3354
content: I've looked at "botifying" eipv, but it is painful because it is in Rust (<@543900561460822016> üëÄ). Could not find a working github actions / API crate for rust, while all of them exists for python / js / ts / ruby.

author: axic3354
content:
> <@!425279588009246720> it sounds like you are able to confirm that `xlab` is one of the authors for https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2765 so I'll leave it to you to merge that (and I recommend helping the user update the email address to GH username as well).
<@!301186049323958275> I asked him to include the username or mark it abandoned, but he was reluctant to add the username and asked not to abandon it üòï

author: sky.cactus
content: Is @xlab in GitHub the same as one of the authors?

author: sky.cactus
content: (I don't know them, so I cannot confirm personally)

author: axic3354
content:
The way I look up the username is the following (and I **should not** be doing this):
- `git blame` the file to check its commit hash
- `get show <hash>` and see what was the PR number
- check the PR on github and see what was the username originally submitting the EIP
- and usually ping that username

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, and that process revealed this user is in fact one of the authors?

author: sky.cactus
content: If so I'll propose a suggestion to update the appropriate author to GitHub username.

author: axic3354
content: Well that user submitted the EIP in the first place üôÇ

author: axic3354
content: So I assume must be the author?

author: sky.cactus
content: Do we know which author is them?

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, GitHub tells me their name.

author: axic3354
content: The first one, if you click on the username you get the name

author: sky.cactus
content: Got it, thanks.

author: axic3354
content: Since we rely on github, the automerger, etc. I think we should just require github username (at least one per EIP) and discourage emails as this is getting rather tiresome in many cases.

author: sky.cactus
content: I support that.

author: axic3354
content: Even if someone responds to an email request, how is the editor supposed to prove that? Copy paste the email verbatim into the PR?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, I agree with the "one GitHub author per EIP minimum".

author: axic3354
content: And no way I have the time to reach out on email pinging people.

author: axic3354
content:
> We *really* need to get the EIP bot to not listen in on forks.  Does anyone have any idea how to fix that?  The bot just recently pinged like 30 people: <https://github.com/vorot93/EIPs/pull/104> because someone merged master into their fork (essentially).
<@!301186049323958275> I have no idea how the automerger was triggered there

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't have any idea where the automerger lives or runs, but I'm almost positive the issue is that it is watching all EIP repository forks.

author: sky.cactus
content: My *guess* is that it is run by CI in a file in the EIPs repository (e.g., Travis) and then when a fork is created Travis sees that fork and starts running CI against it.

author: axic3354
content: It is pinged by travis and apparently there's no check for repo in the automerger: https://github.com/eip-automerger/automerger/issues

author: axic3354
content: Btw it is linked in the EIPs repository README üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: I can't be bothered to read fluff material like the README!  üòõ

author: axic3354
content: Anyway good job on the reviews! Hopefully it is sustainable haha

author: sky.cactus
content: I think once we get the PR count down it will become more sustainable.

author: sky.cactus
content: Especially with the auto-close thing you setup.

author: axic3354
content: Actually on the autoclose, I think we may want to tune it: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2949#issuecomment-689032064

author: axic3354
content: Now we need a full time person implementing the fixes for eipv/automerger üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: We do need someone on-"staff" who *can* fix the automerge bot.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!425279588009246720> Am I incorrect that the whole process starts over from 0 days as soon as anyone comments on the EIP?

author: axic3354
content: I did an automerger fix myself last year (to include the PR number in the commit log), but that was enough python for me.

author: axic3354
content:
> <@!425279588009246720> Am I incorrect that the whole process starts over from 0 days as soon as anyone comments on the EIP?
I think that's how it works, that's why I suggested different time limits. Although it ignores comments from bots apparently.

author: sky.cactus
content: I support your suggested limit changes.

author: sky.cactus
content: Looks like lightclient as well, I say YOLO it.  üòâ

author: axic3354
content: If you scroll up to yesterday, I posted some logs from the stale bot. And it seems to think I'm a bot too, so perhaps ignores my comments ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

author: axic3354
content: Beware you may be considered a bot soon too, and be ignored by the stale bot haha

author: axic3354
content: After reviewing a bunch of ERCs what I miss in many drafts is a description of a flow how the interface is supposed to be used. It seems to be a recurring issue.

author: axic3354
content: I mean those which practically define state machines.

author: sky.cactus
content: Most ERCs are terrible IMO.

author: sky.cactus
content: I *really* want to get them out of the EIPs repository.  üòñ

author: sky.cactus
content: Like 90% of them IMO are just someone defining their app's API or just describing their app.  They have no need to be standardized.

author: axic3354
content: It is a good way to shill üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.  üòï

author: sky.cactus
content: So I'm starting to get into the EIPs that are pretty old (from last year)... I'm really hesitant to touch them and reset the bot timer, but at the same time I really hate that the bot's message says "please respond to the editor feedback" when there was no editor feedback...

author: sky.cactus
content: In hindsight, I wish I would have thought about that before suggesting the bot message wording I did.  üò¢

author: axic3354
content: Should have just kept the vague one I had üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: Like this one, EIP has no feedback on it, and then a year later it is marked as stale: <https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2368>

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, this one had discussion and comments and is green in GitHub and ready for merge, but for some reason it just never was merged: <https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2348>

author: axic3354
content: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2444 and https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2467 are good examples are ERCs lacking clarity on the specification front

author: sky.cactus
content:
Re: <https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2467#issuecomment-689505234>
I dislike that style, but understand why it is used.  I really wish Solidity would have put visibility and modifiers before the parameter list.  üò¢

author: axic3354
content: I dislike using solidity in ERCs but there's no better alternative (I proposed one, but it is not as "expressive" and "accessible").

author: sky.cactus
content: Meh, Solidity doesn't bother me.  People use C++, or Python, or even JavaScript in specifications all the time and I think it makes it appeal to a *much* wider audience that way than some esoteric language that no one knows.

author: sky.cactus
content: I am truly torn on whether to just archive all of these email notifications, or try to work my way through them.  I was planning on rewriting 2718 plus a few other EIPs today and ended up spending all my free time today just doing EIP reviews from the bot's mass closure list.

author: sky.cactus
content: After realizing I was only on page one of two... I'm starting to think I should just archive all and wait for people to comment.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, there are a bunch that I *hope* the author doesn't pursue...

author: axic3354
content: I share the sentiment, I would rather not spend time on reviving dead endeavours, unless someone is persistent.

author: axic3354
content: btw, that was ruthless on #2467, but needed üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content:
> btw, that was ruthless on #2467, but needed üôÇ
üò¨  I did feel bad writing it, the person has put some effort into writing the spec and trying to follow all of the rules.  But at the same time, I really feel like (along with most ERCs) it doesn't need to be standardized.

author: sky.cactus
content: Trying to standardize good ideas via EIPs is my pet peeve.

author: sky.cactus
content: I actually generally like that idea too (which is more than I can say for most ERCs I read).  Just not as a standard.

author: sky.cactus
content: I actually went to the website and looked into the app even, I potentially could use this for paying my employees.

author: sky.cactus
content: (assuming it isn't full of backdoors and upgradability like 95% of apps on Ethereum)

author: axic3354
content: Most regard "upgradeability" as a feature and not as a bug.

author: axic3354
content: I would say it is mostly a "new guard" vs. "old guard" thing in terms of philosophy.

author: sky.cactus
content: Surprisingly, the contract code for this actually looks reasonably good.

author: sky.cactus
content: You mean "people who get censorship resistance" and "people who don't"?  üöé

author: axic3354
content: Instead of building resilient interfaces/design, they resort to the seemingly easiest route: lets upgrade the code if something goes wrong.

author: axic3354
content: Surprisingly many people respond to the ping from the bot

content: I should probably go through the list and look for my own PRs at least...

content: I was thinking about making use of github actions as it seems to be working well and there are frameworks to write them -- except for rust. Then I'd run the validator and create individual comments for those using github actions.

author: axic3354
content:
The problem with the automerger is that both the repository and the deployment (on google appengine) is controlled by Nick and he's just busy with other things.

Actually thought about rewriting the automerger as a github action too, as then it would be completely controlled via the repository and removing the need for this external trigger.

author: lightclient
content: yep, makes sense

author: axic3354
content: And created an org (github.com/eip-guard) we could use to collect all these bots and sources should we wish to proceed.

author: lightclient

content: I would *personally* prefer it if we could have more discussions async via text, but I will admit that getting people to show up to such discussions has proven quite difficult.

author: sky.cactus
content: My vote on the call was in favor of the previously proposed labels because I think either those or your proposed labels are better than the current ones and getting agreement on your proposal (which I did mention) looked like it would delay *any* change.

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree with you that smaller changes are generally better.

author: axic3354
content: Well I guess I will see what this secret proposal is when it is enacted by someone on the repo

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: I think there is a HackMD somewhere with it or something?  Maybe a GitHub issue?  ~~Maybe on the EIPIP repo?~~

author: sky.cactus
content: (not no EIPIP repository)

author: sky.cactus
content: My recommendation <@!425279588009246720> is that as soon as the status change PR is merged, submit a PR that proposes moving to Abandoned with reason.  That way we aren't hold back *all* changes, and we can have a more focused discussion around just the Withdrawn vs Abandoned thing.

author: axic3354
content: The last I heard about this withdrawn/abandoned is in this notes: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/2941#issuecomment-689664324

author: axic3354
content:
> submit a PR that proposes moving to Abandoned with reason

?

I do not propose we keep abandoned, I propose we **rename** abandoned to withdrawn.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, for some reason I thought you were proposing keeping only abandoned and rolling withdrawn into it (it is late here).

author: axic3354
content: **and** introduce a `reason` field.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm fine with either.  I think a reason field is reasonable and withdrawn/abandoned are functionally the same so having a single status is reasonable.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, there isn't really any good reason to list abandoned and withdrawn separately in most cases.

author: axic3354
content: Yes, that is my point, I think there are more than 2 reasons something ends up in that status and then either we have all those as top level states or a single state with a reason.

author: sky.cactus
content: You have my support if you submit a PR after the broader status changes are made.  If you try to block the broader status changes then you probably won't get my support.  üò¨

author: axic3354
content: I should have just made a PR with the above chart back in December and merged it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the current statuses are terrible and think both James's proposal and your proposal are both significantly better, and since James was on the call and you weren't his proposal ended up winning in the "consensus on the call", so that is now what I back just so we can get *something* in.

author: axic3354
content: If/when we get more automation in and certain drafts are blocking automation we could opt to be a bit radical and mark those things as "automatically withdrawn" or "withdrawn due to formatting errors" (given the bots should ignore withdrawn files) and let the authors revive them if they wish.

author: sky.cactus
content:
1. Normalize all `[EIP?###]` to `[EIP-###]`
2. Normalize all `[ERC?###]` to `[ERC-###]`
3. Convert all `[EIP-###](?)` to `[EIP-###](./eip-###.md)`
4. Convert all `[ERC-###](?)` to `[ERC-###](./eip-###.md)`
5. Wait for bot to run.
6. Revert everything the bot complains about.
7. Wait for bot to pass.
8. Get approval from Axic/Lightclient.
9. Merge.
